title: Cleansing the Doors of Perception (Huston Smith) – Part 1
body:
With the public hysteria over the drug war, it's easy for people to confuse the serious scientific research into psychedelics with the baggage of their social abuse. 

Professor Huston Smith, author of The World's Religions and Cleansing the Doors of Perception, and emeritus professor in philosophy and religion at MIT, Syracuse and Berkeley, aspires to introduce sober thinking into this hot topic. 

Join the exploration of the religious significance of entheogenic (God disclosing, from the root: Theos), or psychedelic, plants and chemicals. Learn how research maps chemical changes in the brain during mystical disclosures. Learn how researchers define these substances separately from hallucinogenic substances, a social name that inadvertently connotes deception.

See also: Part 2
teaser: With the public hysteria over the drug war, it's easy for people to confuse the serious scientific research into psychedelics with the baggage of their social abuse.

title: Cleansing the Doors of Perception (Huston Smith) – Part 2
body:
Many great American thinkers of the 60s integrated their experiences from entheogenic (God disclosing, from the root: Theos) substances, or psychedelics, into their serious and dedicated metaphysical search for authentic self-awareness. 

Our conversation continues with Professor Huston Smith, as we explore the positive and constructive experiences these substances can introduce. From curing fears of death to traveling in the realms depicted by the Tibetan Book of the Dead, entheogens can play a pivotal part in integrating profound spiritual experiences.

See also: Part 1
teaser: Many great American thinkers have integrated their experiences from entheogens (God disclosing, from the root: Theos) into their serious and dedicated metaphysical search for authentic self-awareness.

title: Embracing Aging, Change and Dying (Ram Dass) – Part 1
body:
Ram Dass, cultural pioneer for the spiritual renaissance, human potential and psychedelic movements and an inspiration to millions, points us to our greater identity, which includes and transcends that of our physical bodies. 

After a life-transforming stroke, he is glad that he identifies with soul, which doesn't experience illness or death, but at the same time embraces his limited yet transient physical self, through the larger spiritual realization that his suffering has brought him. 

Because he identifies with more, in a sense he is even more human now. By contrast, the same limitation might be a point of contention to a someone who does not include the physical form in their awakening.

See also: Part 2
teaser: Human potential movement pioneer Ram Dass points us to our greater identity, which includes and transcends our physical bodies.

title: Embracing Aging, Change and Dying (Ram Dass) – Part 2
body:
What do you do when aging decreases your mental and physical capacity and punctures your sense of life? Host Jeffrey Mishlove and Ram Dass continue their conversation about the effects of Ram Dass's recent stroke, and Ram Dass explains that the stroke has changed his sense of identity.  

Ram Dass explains that it was easy to identify himself as superficial aspects of his character, for example as a golfer, but since his stroke, he can no longer see himself that way. He can no longer golf, no longer speak as fluently. He must find a deeper meaning of life and definition of himself.  

Mishlove and Ram Dass discuss the lack of respect for elders in this culture, noting that there are very few interviews with people who experience aphasia. Ram Dass offers comforting wisdom and insight.

See also: Part 1
teaser: Join host Jeffrey Mishlove and Ram Dass, author of Still Here and many other books, as they discuss how to handle the physical and mental changes brought on by a stroke, and how to confront death.

title: Body, Nature and the Hypermodern World (Charlene Spretnak) – Part 1
body:
What are the health drawbacks to our focus on economics, technology, progress, and the autonomous individual?  Charlene Spretnak and host Jeffrey Mishlove discuss the "crisis of modernity." 

Spretnak explains that in the modern world, humans are not considered human, but instead homo-economicus. This view impacts not only our emotional fulfillment, but our capacity for improving health.

For the last 400 years, we have believed in a mechanistic model of the body, where we view our bodies as machines rather than viewing them holistically. In her book, The Resurgence of the Real, Spretnak takes an optimistic view and explores the recent shift away from modernity toward the real. 

Even if we have a long way to go, Spretnak and Mishlove agree that our understanding has improved.

See also: Part 2
teaser: Host Jeffrey Mishlove talks with Charlene Spretnak, author of The Resurgence of the Real, about the recent shift in modernity as it relates to our understanding of our bodies.

title: Consciousness, Evolution and Human Survival! (Dr. Stanislav Grof)
body:
Money, power, territory and status, epochs of violence, greed, and social dislocation have rocked humanity throughout history. Today, through the population explosion, industrial revolution and production, these overzealous elements of human nature threaten not only our survival, but the survival of all life on this planet. Are we imposing our unchecked wills at the expense of our relationship to the planet? 

With so much at stake, Dr. Stanislov Grof, world renowned psychotherapist, creator of Holotropic Breathwork, and author of many books, explains how our consciousness informs taking action to address such profound social implications at this crucial time, and to evolve beyond the pitfalls inherent in our unchecked patterns. 

Such questions have been repeatedly discovered and explored, yet today we face the most significant nexus of potential futures in humanity's history. How do we respond?
teaser: The population explosion, industrial revolution and production inflame overzealous elements of human nature, such as greed and violence, threatening not only our survival, but the survival of all life on this planet. How do we respond?

title: From Science to God (Peter Russell) – Part 1
body:
How can we understand consciousness in terms of our scientific understanding of the material world? Peter Russell explains that for years, the idea of consciousness was ignored by the scientific community. Recently, scientists have begun trying to provide a scientific explanation of consciousness, to no avail. Russell argues that they are asking the wrong question.  

If we believe the material world is real, as many do, then we believe that it must be the cause of consciousness and perceptions. Russell says that consciousness cannot be explained through our belief of the material world, because the material world that we perceive is nothing more than a recreation that our mind makes. In the end, the only thing we can be sure of is our consciousness, not of the material world.

See also: Part 2
teaser: Host Jeffrey Mishlove talks with Peter Russell, author of From Science to God, about how to reconcile consciousness and the material world.

title: From Science to God (Peter Russell) – Part 2
body:
Could there be a scientific explanation of consciousness that is outside the realm we consider reality? Host Peter Russell continues his discussion with Jeffrey Mishlove about consciousness in the material world.  

Russell provides a clear summary of the Theory of Relativity and its implications. He explains that as mass speeds up, space and time decrease and mass increases. This is why it is impossible for mass to move at the speed of light; mass would reach infinity, requiring an infinite amount of energy to move it, which doesn't exist. 

Light, however, does move at the speed of light. Because of this, from light's perspective there is no space or time.  Russell argues that because consciousness is not matter and has no mass, consciousness does not exist in space or time and is more like light.

See also: Part 1
teaser: Host Jeffrey Mishlove talks with Peter Russell, author of From Science to God, about how to understand the inner-light from a scientific perspective, which is surprisingly similar to our spiritual understanding.

title: Godseed (Dr. Jean Houston)
body:
Jean Houston helps us explore Christ through her discussion with host Jeffrey Mishlove about her book Godseed.  

Houston shares that she wrote Godseed in a way that enables readers to follow the story and really be part of it, taking readers into being reborn as the Holy Child and providing them with exercises that teach deep healing and deep recognition. She speaks of the greatness of Christ, and his power to inspire greatness and call forth the immense possibility of humanity.
teaser: Jean Houston discusses her book, Godseed, with host Jeffrey Mishlove.  Houston shares that she wrote the book in a way that makes it emotionally accessible to readers, and she offers messages of inspiration about humanity and our possibility of greatness.

title: Green Psychology (Ralph Metzner) – Part 1
body:
How did we lose the connection to nature in our psychology? Host Jeffrey Mishlove and Ralph Metzner, author of Green Psychology, discuss the stages in history that developed the current psyche of domination, creating the current environmental crisis. 

Although extinctions and changes in the planet have occurred before, they have never been caused by a single species.  They discuss indigenous people and their greater connection to the planet, and Metzner argues that our encouragement of third and fourth world nations to develop is similar to colonialism.

See also: Part 2
teaser: Host Jeffrey Mishlove talks with Ralph Metzner, author of Green Psychology, about how our psychology, especially in the West, has recently shifted from nature-centric toward isolation.

title: Green Psychology (Ralph Metzner) – Part 2
body:
Can we attain a feeling of connectedness with nature? Jeffrey Mishlove and host Ralph Metzner continue their conversation about our relationship with nature. 

Metzner explains that in transforming our relationship with the Earth, we learn humility. Following nature puts us in a humble position. 

They discuss the idea of “pests.” Metzner shares an example of a time when ants were invading his kitchen. He stopped to consciously consider what they were doing: finding food. He was able to relate to them, so he gave them a cookie and asked them to leave. He found that through his change of consciousness and new found respect, they responded. Metzner explains that we must change our entire vision of life and our relationship with the planet.

See also: Part 1
teaser: Host Jeffrey Mishlove talks with Ralph Metzner, author of Green Psychology, about how to transform our relationship with the Earth.

title: The Traditional, the Modern and the Postmodern (Huston Smith)
body:
Explore the confluence of value systems in our age — the traditional, modern, and postmodern — with Huston Smith, a world renowned speaker and author of The World’s Religions. 

At one time, everyone lived under the umbrella of a traditional worldview. With the rise of modern science in the 16th and 17th centuries, a new era began, the era of modernity. Modernity lasted through the mid-20th century when it phased into what we now call the postmodern world. Each of these periods recognizes a unique and integrally important gift in human development. 

From learning to draw our livelihood from the earth, to deepening our human relations and social patterns, to exploring our relationship to the Cosmos, each era had its own special genius — but it is only by integrating all three aspects that mankind will realize its potential.
teaser: Explore the confluence of value systems in our age: the traditional, modern, and postmodern. Each era recognizes a unique and integrally important gift in human development.

title: The Heart of the Mind (Russell Targ) – Part 1
body:
Can you have a direct experience of God without the need for belief? Russell Targ, physicist and author of The Heart of the Mind, explores how to know God for those who are not particularly prone to belief. 

Through his own meticulous research into psychic abilities and personal experience, Russell explains that it is possible to have a direct experience of God or to reside in love without having to believe anything that would be offensive to the discerning modern scientific mind. What we discover is that the idea of non-locality in physics is coherent with what the ancient Vedic and mystic scholars taught 2500 years ago – that if you sit and observe you'll notice that separateness is an illusion. 

Central to the teachings of the Buddha, Jesus, Patanjali and many others, the experiential truth that we are all one is now discernible via science as well as through religious or mystical belief.

See also: Part 2
teaser: Can you have a direct experience of God without the need for belief? Central to the teachings of the Buddha, Jesus, Patanjali and many others, the experiential truth that we are all one is now discernible via physics, as well as through religious or mystical belief.

title: The Heart of the Mind (Russell Targ) – Part 2
body:
Centuries after their split, science and spirituality are again finding common ground. Thanks to the physics principle of non-locality, which mirrors the mystical teachings of non-separateness, you no longer must sacrifice your discerning mind for a direct experience of God or love. 

Happiness will not be found on the material plane, Russell Targ says. 

In Silicon Valley, for example, everyone is looking for happiness, and they look for it on the material plane — a new house, a new girlfriend, a new car — thinking that will bring them happiness. But that never works. Happiness is an inside job. The path you want to be on leads to transcendence. If you quiet your mind, this kind of experience is available.

See also: Part 1
teaser: Russell Targ and host Jeffrey Mishlove continue their conversation about having a direct experience of God without the need for belief, and how quieting the mind and letting go of attachments are the common practice of those who, through the centuries, have described mystical experiences.

title: Psychic Healing Research (Dr. Elisabeth Targ) – Part 1
body:
Dr. Elisabeth Targ, from the California Pacific Medical Center, discusses the psychic and spiritual side of healing. She loks at the impact of a spiritual lifestyle, spiritual practices and spiritual techniques from the perspective of a researcher.  

The Institute for Health & Healing is set up for healing and personal growth. There are two components to the center: healing that is done by gifted healers, and people who are ill who are involved in support groups for self healing.   

Dr. Targ created a program in which Individuals can participate in personal exploration or a personal practice to work toward a more spiritual form of inner healing. During the program, she studies and is amazed by the dramatic effects that spiritual healing has on recovery from illness.

See also: Part 2
teaser: Dr. Elisabeth Targ discusses how psychic and spiritual forms of healing are beginning to make a breakthrough in the medical world. She talks about the effectiveness of this new practice, and discusses the demand for doctors and physicians to enter this new realm of healing.

title: Psychic Healing Research (Dr. Elisabeth Targ) – Part 2
body:
Dr. Elisabeth Targ, from the California Pacific Medical Center, shares her pivotal research in the field of psychic healing. 

In one method of healing, known as Distant Mental Influence, patients show a tremendous recovery advantage when they receive healing thoughts from afar, even when the patients are unaware of the healing effort. 

Dr. Targ scientifically researches the impact of spirituality through lifestyles, practices and techniques, and her studies show the dramatic effects that spiritual healing has on illness. One goal is to further research whether spiritual growth can help actually heal physical illness.

See also: Part 1
teaser: Dr. Elisabeth Targ shares her pivotal research in the field of psychic healing and the impact of a spiritual lifestyle.

title: Jump Time (Dr. Jean Houston) – Part 1
body:
With host Jeffrey Mishlove, Jean Houston, author of Jump Time, discusses society in transition. Jump time refers to her belief that something exhilarating, something unique is about to happen, and she urges us to wake-up and recognize that social structures are breaking down because they come from old industrial societies.  

Jean tells host Jeffrey Mishlove that the whole sense of human identity and responsibly is changing, and uses the term Jump Time to refer to the present moment in which this is happening. She addresses the concept of whole-system transition where nothing looks the same as it did before. 

See also: Part 2
teaser: Jean Houston, author of Jump Time, discusses society in transition. Jump time refers her belief that something exhilarating and unique is about to happen.

title: Jump Time (Dr. Jean Houston) — Part 2
body:
Host Jeffrey Mishlove and Jean Houston continue their discussion on Jump Time. 

Jean discusses how changing the veil of context when relating to people helps us connect with them on a new level, how our wounds and vulnerabilities enable us to become deeply vulnerable and available to the needs of others. 

She discusses our wounded world and that a new consciousness is required to heal it because, as Albert Einstein once said, "The consciousness that created the problem is not going to be the same consciousness that fixes the problem." 

See also: Part 1
teaser: Continuing their discussion, Host Jeffrey Mishlove and Jean Houston discuss how the wakening of humanity has been hidden in our culture for thousands of years, and that we are finally at a time when the wakening is about to occur, and she calls it "Jump Time."

title: Intuitive Healing (Dr. Judith Orloff)
body:
How can we get in touch with our inner-self and use our intuition to guide us, regardless of our life situation at the time?

Dr. Judith Orloff assures us that intuition is available to everyone and offers steps to achieve awareness of it. Whether we experience déjà-vu or have intermittent knowing, she tells us that intuition is an incredible source of wisdom and that tuning in to our embodied wisdom is essential to informing how we live our lives. 

Discover how to look at any experience, including illness, through your intuition as a way to open your heart.
teaser: Host Jeffrey Mishlove and Judith Orloff, psychiatrist and author of Guide to Intuitive Healing Intuition, discuss why we need to be in touch with our intuition at all times, and Judith provides concrete steps to accomplish that, especially when facing illness.

title: Why Religion Matters (Huston Smith)
body:
Have you wondered what exists beyond our rational everyday consciousness? 

Join professor and mystic Huston Smith, author of Why Religion Matters, as he and host Jeffrey Mishlove discuss what quantum physics, philosophy and religion have to say about the reality of existence — and why both science and religion are right, for very different reasons.
teaser: Join professor and mystic Huston Smith, author of Why Religion Matters, on a fascinating in-depth look at modern mystical and religious beliefs through two lenses: that of science and of religion.

title: Spiritual Anthropology (Joan Halifax) – Part 1
body:
Visiting Tibet on pilgrimage and retreat, Joan Halifax, Roshi of the Upaya Zen Center in Santa Fe, New Mexico, anthropologist, and author of many books, describes an extraordinary mix of beauty and emotion. 

Bear witness to the spirit of the Lhimi Valley, last of the untouched land of the Tibetan peoples. Encounter the heartbreak of their diaspora and their palpable abandonment since the heads of all lineages have left, including the Dalai Lama and the young Karmapa. 

For the Tibetans both spiritually and manifest, theirs is a story of the journey that never ends.

See also: Part 2
teaser: Visiting Tibet on pilgrimage and retreat, Joan Halifax, Roshi of the Upaya Zen Center in Santa Fe, New Mexico, bears witness to the land and its people – an extraordinary mix of beauty and emotion on a journey that never ends.

title: Spiritual Anthropology (Joan Halifax) – Part 2
body:
Beginner's Mind, as Suzuki Roshi calls it, a mind of pure and open inquiry, is one of the most important things that arises in meditation. 

Growing up a war baby in the 60s, the life of Joan Halifax, anthropologist and Roshi of the Upaya Zen Center in Santa Fe New Mexico, has been about exploring suffering from a place of openness. Her current work, both with dying people and with those on death row in the penitentiary system, continues to deepen her experience of compassion. 

Learn about her calling to answer the impulse to go down into the depths and to witness compassion and love for the benefit of all sentient beings.

See also: Part 1
teaser: Join Joan Halifax as we learn to bring openness, compassion, and raison d'etre to our deep suffering in life.

title: The Cultural Creatives (Paul H. Ray)
body:
Cultural Creatives are a fascinating demographic, a major mainstream subculture of American society that represent a collective emergence of progressive values, beliefs and lifestyles. Discovered by sociologist Paul H. Ray, co-author of The Cultural Creatives, they comprise 50 million Americans, 26% of the population. 

These are the people who take seriously environment and ecology, personal growth and development, relationships, contemplative practices, and much more. Ray has studied this shift in values and lifestyle that has been happening over the past 40 years. 

World-centric, rather than traditionalist or modernist, Cultural Creatives combine an extensive inner development with with an expansive, compassionate and sustainable planetary view.
teaser: Cultural Creatives are a fascinating demographic, a major mainstream subculture of American society who represent a collective emergence of progressive values, beliefs and lifestyles.

title: Goddesses in Older Women (Dr. Jean Shinoda Bolen)
body:
What can the goddess of the Greek, Hindu, and Egyptian mythologies teach us about the experience as an older woman?  Mishlove and Jean Shinoda Bolen examine the stories of goddesses like Athena, Metis, Hecate, Kali, and Sekhmet.  Bolen says that the key to becoming a "juicy crone" is finding a balance of the energies of all the goddesses.  

Each of their characters and stories has wisdom to offer, but you don't want to be caught up in just one of them.  Bolen says that not everyone gets wise when they age, but the potential to become wise ripens.  She emphasizes the need for cultivating wisdom and compassion.  In addition to feeling compassion, action must follow.
teaser: Jeffrey Mishlove interviews Dr. Jean Shinoda Bolen, author of Goddesses of Older Women, about how to enrich the experience of becoming an older woman, or a "crone," through stories of the Goddesses throughout the world.

title: After the Ecstasy, the Laundry (Dr. Jack Kornfield)
body:
Dr. Jack Kornfield, founder of the Insight Meditation Society and author of After the Ecstasy, the Laundry, tells us that enlightenment may be a transformation of the heart, but not necessarily of the body or personality. 

Dr. Kornfield discusses the nature of enlightenment, spiritual maturity and his experience in an ever-evolving practice.
teaser: Is it a myth that after enlightenment one lives happily ever after? Why do many who reach high states of enlightenment retain their very human problems?

title: Shaman Healer Sage (Alberto Villoldo)
body:
Explore the path of the Shaman and healer with Alberto Villoldo, author of  Shaman, Healer, Sage. Villoldo differentiates between healing and curing — he is in the business of healing and doctors are in the business of curing. Often tremendous cures arise from healing, and one can access a state of wellness and experience infinity in communion with all of life.  

Villoldo explains what he calls systemic healing, healing of the whole system to help disinhibit the immune response so that the person's body comes back into health.
teaser: Alberto Villoldo and host Jeffrey Mishlove discuss the power of systemic healing and the difference between cures and healing.

title: Dance of the Four Winds (Alberto Villoldo)
body:
Host Jeffrey Mishlove and Dr. Alberto Villoldo, author of Dance of the Four Winds, explore the path of the Inca Medicine Wheel. Dr. Villoldo believes that one of the greatest contributions of the shaman's body of knowledge is the journey beyond death and the idea that we can assist a loved one in making the journey back home. 

He discusses how Western culture is motivated by the fear of death, whereas the Shaman has an experience of infinity and of a self that is not subject to death. He believes that the realization of knowing that we are free from the grip of time, death and disease is the most healing experience that we can have as human beings.
teaser: Dr. Alberto Villoldo discusses how the Shamanic approach to life, as lived by the Andean Incas of Peru, is a healing and powerful way to look at life and death, and how it relates to us.

title: The Sanskrit Tradition (Dean Brown) – Part 2
body:
Dean Brown, translator of The Upanishads and the Yoga Sutras, discusses the various types of yoga. Many are most familiar with Hatha Yoga, but as you will discover there are many other forms, including good deeds, prayer and knowledge.

He also explores the word origins of English and how the words of Sanskrit are related to common words we use today.  Brown, who is also a physicist, explains how the Vedic traditions have logical roots in physics.

See also: Part 1
teaser: Dean Brown discusses The Upanishads and the Yoga Sutras, which he has translated, and explains how these writings relate to science.

title: A Personal Journey (Dr. Jean Shinoda Bolen)
body:
Illuminating the wellspring of women's spirituality, Dr. Jean Shinoda Bolen, Jungian analyst, shares what esoteric culture and authentic mysticism have in common: the interior experience, rather than the object or word which point to it. 

In a patriarchal culture, the church or other structure can usurp the words associated with spiritual experience. This unconsciously prevents self-recognition and integration of direct, authentic mystical experience outside of the currently accepted ideology.
teaser: Illuminating women's spirituality, Dr. Jean Shinoda Bolen, Jungian analyst, shares what esoteric culture and authentic mysticism have in common.

title: Time and the I Ching with Terence McKenna
body: Terence McKenna examines Carl Jung's notion of synchronicity, or meaningful coincidence, as it applies to the Chinese I Ching. He proposes that the 64 hexagrams actually contain a specific mathematical structure which models both time itself and the human mind. This common structure, he maintains, accounts for the remarkable success of the I Ching in providing guidance into human affairs.
teaser: Terence McKenna  proposes that the 64 hexagrams of the I Ching contain a specific mathematical structure which models both time and the human mind.

title: Aliens and Archetypes with Terence McKenna
body: Do UFOs originate as psychic projections from our own minds? The late Terence McKenna, a leading thinker in the area of alternative realities, suggests that regardless of their origin and material existence, UFOs seem to challenge the authority of science, and that their chief function may be to offset the imbalances in our contemporary culture.
teaser: Terence McKenna suggests that regardless of their origin and material existence, the chief function of UFOs may be to offset the imbalances in our contemporary culture.

title: The Human Future with Terence McKenna
body: Human survival requires that we become aware of our responsibility for the future. Terence McKenna proposes four key elements of a future mandala: feminism, space exploration, cybernetics and hallucinogens.
teaser: Terence McKenna proposes four key elements of a future mandala: feminism, space exploration, cybernetics and hallucinogens.

title: Hallucinogens and Culture with Terence McKenna
body: Hallucinogenic substances have been instrumental in the foundation of many aspects of our cultural heritage. In this challenging program, Terence McKenna suggests ways in which hallucinogenic plants have been associated with spiritual traditions in ancient India, in the Amazon and in medieval Europe.
teaser: Terence McKenna suggests ways in which hallucinogenic plants have been associated with spiritual traditions in ancient India, in the Amazon and in medieval Europe.

title: Imagery and the Alphabet Part 1 with Leonard Shlain
body: In ancient times, says Leonard Shlain, human societies universally worshipped the image of a goddess. Sometime about 5,000 years ago a massive shift occurred in which the sex of the deity changed. He presents his hypothesis that this change is related to the introduction of the alphabet and its effects upon the human brain. He notes that in the west, witchhunts and other effects of male-dominant society occurred at a time of rising literacy. He also suggests that the rise of feminism in the twentieth century is correlated with increased use of imagery as a result of film and television.
teaser: Leonard Shlain discusses the introduction of the alphabet and its effects upon the human brain.

title: Imagery and the Alphabet Part 2 with Leonard Shlain
body: In the second part of a conversation with Jeffrey Mishlove, Leonard Shlain discusses the introduction of the alphabet and its effects upon the human brain. In ancient times, human societies universally worshipped the image of a goddess. Sometime about 5,000 years ago a massive shift occurred in which the sex of the deity changed. He presents his hypothesis that this change is related to the introduction of the alphabet and its effects upon the human brain. He notes that in the west, witchhunts and other effects of male-dominant society occurred at a time of rising literacy. He also suggests that the rise of feminism in the twentieth century is correlated with increased use of imagery as a result of film and television.
teaser: In the second part of a conversation with Jeffrey Mishlove, Leonard Shlain discusses the introduction of the alphabet and its effects upon the human brain.

title: Synchronicity and the Holographic Universe Part 1 with Michael Talbot
body: Michael Talbot discusses the holographic model of brain functioning and the "implicate order" model of quantum physics. He proposes that these two models combined explain many unsolved mysteries in both brain functioning (such as memory and vision) and quantum physics (such as the problem of hidden variables and quantum interconnectedness).
teaser: Michael Talbot discusses the holographic model of brain functioning and the "implicate order" model of quantum physics.

title: Synchronicity and the Holographic Universe Part 2 with Michael Talbot
body: Michael Talbot discusses the holographic model of brain functioning and the "implicate order" model of quantum physics. He proposes that these two models combined explain many unsolved mysteries in both brain functioning (such as memory and vision) and quantum physics (such as the problem of hidden variables and quantum interconnectedness).
teaser: Michael Talbot discusses the holographic model of brain functioning and the "implicate order" model of quantum physics.

title: The Holographic Brain with Karl Pribram
body: With a better understanding of neurological functioning, says Karl Pribram, M.D., we may find the groundwork for a new approach to understanding spiritual and mystical experiences. The late Dr. Pribram, professor of neuropsychology at Stanford University and author of Languages of the Brain, is best known for his "holonomic" theory of brain functioning.
teaser: Karl Pribram seeks a new approach to understanding spiritual and mystical experiences.

title: From Here to Alternity with John Lilly
body: John Lilly reveals a lifelong pattern of deep inner exploration, beginning with his psychoanalysis in the 1940s, his development of the sensory isolation tank in the 1950s, his dolphin communication research in the 1960s and his experiments with psychoactive drugs through the 1980s. He describes telepathic communication with cetaceans and his own experiences of telepathic contact with extraterrestrials (which he now says were illusory).
teaser: John Lilly reveals a lifelong pattern of deep inner exploration, including telepathic communication with cetaceans.

title: Determinism and Free Will with Arthur Young
body: Free will and purpose are not inconsistent with a universe subject to law. In fact, says Arthur Young, free will would be ineffective without a determinate world to act upon. Young, philosopher and inventor of the Bell helicopter, discusses the difference between determinism--the belief that everything acts according to law--and pre-destination or fate.
teaser: Arthur Young, philosopher and inventor of the Bell helicopter, discusses the difference between determinism--the belief that everything acts according to law--and pre-destination or fate.

title: Time and Destiny with Charles Muses
body: The qualitative and cyclical nature of time is the subject of this fascinating interview with the late mathematician, physicist and philosopher Charles Muses, Ph.D., author of Destiny and Control in Human Systems and The Lion Path. Drawing on quantum physics and geometry, Dr. Muses shows how these cyclic patterns can be understood and developed through the cultivation of intuition and feeling with resonant timing.
teaser: Charles Muses discusses the qualitative and cyclical nature of time.
